dataset_list.title: Figure 1.1: Despite incomes growing for the poorest 20% of people, inequality has increased and the gap is projected to widen
Figure 1.2: In recent years, ODA in support of social/welfare services has accounted for a similar proportion as in the 1990s
Figure 1.3: Global progress in reducing poverty was mainly driven by a sharp decrease in the number of people living in extreme poverty in East Asia largely as a result of economic growth
Figure 1.4: In 2030, poverty will become increasingly concentrated in sub-Saharan Africa
Figure 1.5: Around 30 countries can be identified as most at risk of being left behind based on a combination of poverty, vulnerability and human development indicators
Figure 1.6: Extreme poverty is increasingly focused in certain subnational areas
Figure 1.7: Young and older people are more likely to be living in extreme poverty and be left behind
Figure 2.10 (left): More ODA goes to countries with lower countries with low government resources…
Figure 2.11 (right): …however, ODA per poor person is significantly in lower government revenues
Figure 2.12: Growth in ODA to LDCs has lagged behind overall ODA growth
Figure 2.13: ODA to countries identified as being left behind is flatlining while ODA spent elsewhere is growing
Figure 2.14: Adaptation ODA is not effectively targeting the people most vulnerable to climate change
Figure 2.15: Loans have grown much faster than other forms of ODA in recent years
Figure 2.16 (left): Large amounts of ODA loans in 2016 went to countries with high poverty levels…
Figure 2.17 (right): …and to countries with low government revenue
Figure 2.18: The flow of ODA in 2016 (US$ bn)
Figure 2.19: Overall, most ODA is channelled via public-sector bodies
Figure 2.1: Net ODA has grown in $ terms since the 1960s but not as a share of donors’ GNI
Figure 2.20: Less ODA is channelled through the public sector in countries being left behind
Figure 2.21: Humanitarian aid has grown much more quickly than other ODA since 2012
Figure 2.22: Proportions of ODA to Education, Other social services and General budget support have fallen
Figure 2.23: There are clear differences across sector allocations of ODA between countries at different levels of extreme poverty
Figure 2.24: Sector allocations of ODA to countries being left behind and other developing countries differ, but social protection remains among the lowest for both

Figure 2.25: Since 2002, ODA to countries being left behind has become increasingly concentrated on health and humanitarian interventions, while budget support and aid to business and education has fallen
Figure 2.26: Total development cooperation from other government providers stood at US$25 billion in 2016
Figure 2.2: Since 1970, some donors have seen falling levels of ODA as a % of GNI, but most have increased their proportions
Figure 2.3: An additional US$1.5 trillion of ODA could be disbursed by 2030 if all donors achieved 0.7% by 2030
Figure 2.4: The proportion of ODA allocated to specific countries has fallen rapidly in recent years
Figure 2.5: ODA spent within donor countries and not allocated to specific developing countries has risen rapidly
Figure 2.6: Of the ODA allocated to specific countries, more than half goes to countries in sub-Saharan Africa and South and Central Asia (US$ bn, %)
Figure 2.7: There is only a small difference in proportions of ODA received by countries with the highest and the lowest levels of extreme poverty
Figure 2.8 (left): Although more ODA goes to countries with more poor people…

Figure 2.8 and Figure 2.9: 2 Bar Charts, 1st depicting ODA funding amounts (in US$ billions) by numbers of people in extreme poverty, 2nd depicting proportional amount per poor person by the same groupings. 2016 figures.
Figure 2.9 (right):…the amounts are nowhere near proportional  to the scale of poverty
Figure 3.10: In aggregate, all international financing flows have been increasing with private flows increasing the fastest overall
Figure 3.11: Non-ODA flows are far smaller where poverty is greatest and where domestic public resources are lowest
Figure 3.12: Excluding ODA, countries most at risk of being left behind receive the least international financing (per capita)
Figure 3.13: The combined portfolios of European DFIs have grown by 86% between 2009 and 2016
Figure 3.14: Non-ODA financing targets infrastructure and business and industry more than social sectors
Figure 3.15: Districts with the highest poverty tend to have proportionally less resources
Figure 3.1: Bar chart depicting values (US$ billions) for domestic resources in developing countries and international finance inflows and outflows by sector. Figures for year 2016.
Figure 3.1: Domestic resources in developing countries are 12 times larger than international finance flows to developing countries, of which commercial sources of finance dominate
Figure 3.2: Commercial long-term debt and FDI are the two largest sources of international financing to developing countries
Figure 3.3: In aggregate, domestic public resources have increased by 55% since 2008 but growth has slowed
Figure 3.4: Domestic public resources are lowest where extreme poverty is highest
Figure 3.5: Countries being left behind will see slower growth in domestic public resources than other developing countries
Figure 3.6: In many sub-Saharan African countries there is potential to grow the tax base, but also a need to increase tax potential
Figure 4.1: Various initiatives are pushing for the opening of domestic and international data sources
Figure 4.2: The availability and openness of development data varies across different dimensions of sustainable development

Figure 4.3 introduces a conceptual model framework that can be used to prioritise efforts in specific contexts. At each stage of delivery (planning, implementation and evaluation) it assesses demand for data at local, national and international levels, and an indication of where the challenges of both supply and use of the data are most urgent. Drawing on limited available case study evidence for this report, it then applies the framework to identify where key challenges
Figure 4.3: The extent and urgency of challenges related to data use can be measured across levels of intervention and stages of delivery
Figure 5.1: Business as usual means uneven and unequal progress for people
Figure 5.2: For countries being left behind – both ODA and other external sources will fail to close the gap

Figure 5.3 shows, this challenge is likely to be most acute in countries furthest behind. It highlights the challenges in education – a fundamental enabler of long-term development and economic growth.
Figure 5.3: Business as usual will leave many poverty-critical sectors like education underfunded particularly in those countries furthest behind
Figure 3.7: Since 2000, domestic commercial resources have grown substantially but, excluding China, growth has been slowing down
Figure 3.8: Domestic commercial resources are lowest where poverty is highest
Figure 3.9: Most Filipino business investments targeted SDGs 11 (34%) and 4 (28%)
